revision.text:
{{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of Greece.svg|150px]]}} '''Corruption''' is a problem in Greece.<ref name="guardian.co.uk">Inman, Phillip (9 September 2012) [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/sep/09/greece-tax-evasion-professional-classes?CMP=twt_gu Primary Greek tax evaders are the professional classes] The Guardian. Retrieved 6 October 2012</ref><ref name="Ethnos Forodiafygi">{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22770&subid=2&pubid=29345 |script-title=el:Πτώση της φοροδιαφυγής στο 41,6% από 49% το τελευταίο εξάμηνο |year=2006 |publisher=Ethnos |accessdate=12 October 2011|language=el}}</ref > [[Transparency International]] stated in 2012 that corruption had played a major role in causing the [[Greek financial crisis]].<ref>[https://www.transparency.org/news/feature/greece_the_cost_of_a_bribe ''The Cost of a Bribe'' Transparency International, Surveys, 3 April 2012]</ref> [[Tax evasion]] was described by Greek politicians as "a national sport"—with up to €30 billion per year going uncollected, according to a 2012 estimate.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21565657-greek-tax-dodgers-are-being-outed-national-sport-no-more |work=The Economist |title=A national sport no more |date=3 November 2012}}</ref> A 2016 estimate indicated that between €11 billion and €16 billion per annum were not collectable.<ref name="keeptalkinggreece.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.keeptalkinggreece.com/2017/03/23/tax-evasion-in-greece-between-e11bn-e16bn-annually/|title=Tax evasion in Greece between €11bn and €16bn annually|website=www.keeptalkinggreece.com|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> Other significant amounts were uncollected due to VAT (sales tax) fraud<ref>{{cite web|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2016/09/06/vat-gap-greece-lost-5-bln-euros-in-uncollected-vat-revenue/|title=VAT Gap: Greece Lost 5 Bln Euros in Uncollected VAT Revenue - GreekReporter.com|website=greece.greekreporter.com|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> and smuggling.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.dianeosis.org/en/2016/06/tax-evasion-in-greece/|title=Tax Evasion in Greece – A Study - Dianeosis|first=Dianeosis|last=©|date=22 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref>In 2016, the [[OECD]], Greece and the [[European Commission]] launched a project to increase integrity and reduce corruption in Greece through technical empowerment of the Greek authorities for the implementation of Greece’s National Anti-Corruption Action Plan (NACAP).<ref>[http://www.oecd.org/corruption/greece-oecd-anti-corruption.htm Greece-OECD project: Technical support on anti-corruption]</ref>
[[Political corruption]] is acknowledged as a significant problem by many observers, but some believe its size has been overstated by international media.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
The government’s anti-corruption efforts have not been evaluated as effective, according to several sources, which has been attributed to poor enforcement of anti-corruption legislation and the ineffectiveness of anti-corruption agencies. Anti-corruption agencies have been hindered by excessive political influence and continuous replacement of staff. Recent involvement of high-ranking public officials in corruption cases has been reported in the media.<ref>{{cite web|title=Greece Corruption Profile- Political Climate|url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/europe-central-asia/greece/show-all.aspx|publisher=Business Anti-Corruption Portal|accessdate=16 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2012 Human Rights Reports: Greece|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2012/eur/204291.htm|publisher=The US Department of State|accessdate=16 December 2013}}</ref>
== Alleged origin of Greek corruption == Commentators both within and outside Greece have attributed this flaw in Greek culture to a mismanagement of [[Ottoman Greece]] by the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In Ottoman-occupied Greece [[tax resistance]] became a form of patriotism,<ref>{{cite news|last=Itano|first=Nicole|title=Taxing Times in Greece|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1958721,00.html|accessdate=10 September 2012|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=15 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Reguly|first=Eric|title=The roots of the Greek tragedy: bloated bureaucracy and tax evasion|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/the-roots-of-the-greek-tragedy-bloated-bureaucracy-and-tax-evasion/article582943/|accessdate=10 September 2012|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=10 June 2011|location=Toronto}}</ref> and sometimes a condition for survival. Property and commercial tax systems were left in shambles.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rozenweig|first=Luc|author2=Stephane Monclare |title=Pour En Finir Avec Crise|journal=[[Politique Internationale]]|date=Spring 2012|issue=135|url=http://www.politiqueinternationale.com/revue/read2.php?id_revue=135&id=1099&content=texte&search=|accessdate=10 September 2012}} This is a transcript of an interview with [[Jean-Claude Juncker]] in which he mentions the Ottoman impact upon Greece's property and commercial tax systems.</ref> Greece became independent in 1822, but the corruption in modern Greece and the resistance to pay taxes to [[Ottoman Empire]] Era is connected by the fact that part of the ethnic Greek officials of the Ottoman Empire kept their positions after Greek independence and established the way the Greek state was run. Immediately after independence, Greeks were subjected to a heavy tax burden caused by the debt accumulated during the independence war, which was combined with the poverty and devastation caused by the war. Tax evasion was, however, a larger problem among the high-ranking officials, who were accustomed to being unchecked by the Ottomans and sought to preserve that status in the Greek state.
== Extent of Greek tax evasion and corruption == [[File:Vatopedi monastery 2006.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Vatopedi monastery]], which dates from the 10th century. The leadership of the monastery allegedly was involved in corrupt activities, working in collusion with corrupt Greek government officials to [[embezzle]] government funds.<ref name=lewis>Michael Lewis, "[http://www.vanityfair.com/business/features/2010/10/greeks-bearing-bonds-201010?printable=true Beware of Greeks Bearing Bonds]." ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', 1 October 2010.</ref>]]
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;float:right;margin:1em;" |+ Corruption Perceptions Index 2008 (before the Greek debt crisis): Worst EU Performers <ref name="Corruption 2008">{{cite news |url=https://www.transparency.org/research/cpi/cpi_2008/0 |title= Transparency International Corruption Perceptions Index 2008 |work= Transparency International|date= |accessdate= 27 October 2018 }}</ref> |- ! Country ! CPI Score 2008 (World Rank) |- | Bulgaria | style="padding-left: 2em" | 3.6 (72) |- | Romania | style="padding-left: 2em" |3.8 (70) |- | Poland | style="padding-left: 2em" |4.6 (58) |- | Lithuania | style="padding-left: 2em" |4.6 (58) |- | Greece | style="padding-left: 2em" |4.7 (57) |- | Italy | style="padding-left: 2em" | 4.8 (55) |- | Latvia | style="padding-left: 2em" | 5.0 (52) |- | Slovakia | style="padding-left: 2em" | 5.0 (52) |- | Hungary | style="padding-left: 2em" | 5.1 (47) |- | Czech Republic | style="padding-left: 2em" | 5.2 (45) |- | Malta | style="padding-left: 2em" | 5.8 (36) |- | Portugal | style="padding-left: 2em" | 6.1 (32) |}
Before the crisis, Greece was one of EU's worst performers according to [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perception Index]] <ref name="Corruption 2008"/>(see table); by 2017, the respective score remained near the bottom of the EU <ref name="Corruption 2017">{{cite news |url=https://www.transparency.org/news/feature/corruption_perceptions_index_2017| title= Corruption Perceptions Index 2017 |work= Transparency International|date= 21 February 2018 |accessdate= 27 October 2018 }}</ref>.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;float:right;margin:1em;" |+ Shadow Economy (% of GDP) in 2017 (Selected EU Countries) <ref name="Shadow IMF 2017">{{cite news |url=https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WP/Issues/2018/01/25/Shadow-Economies-Around-the-World-What-Did-We-Learn-Over-the-Last-20-Years-45583| title= Shadow Economies Around the World: What Did We Learn Over the Last 20 Years?|work= IMF|date=January 2018 |accessdate= 27 October 2018 }}</ref> |- ! Country ! Shadow Economy (% of GDP) |- | Estonia | style="padding-left: 2em" | 24.6 |- | Malta | style="padding-left: 2em" |23.6 |- | Hungary | style="padding-left: 2em" |22.4 |- | Slovenia | style="padding-left: 2em" |22.4 |- | Poland | style="padding-left: 2em" |22.2 |- | Greece | style="padding-left: 2em" | 21.5 |- | Italy | style="padding-left: 2em" | 19.8 |- | Spain | style="padding-left: 2em" | 17.2 |- | Belgium | style="padding-left: 2em" | 15.6 |- | France | style="padding-left: 2em" | 12.8 |- | Sweden | style="padding-left: 2em" | 12.1 |- | Germany | style="padding-left: 2em" | 10.4 |}
Data for 2012 indicated that the Greek "shadow economy" or "underground economy", from which little or no tax was collected, was a full 24.3% of GDP - compared with 28.6% for Estonia, 26.5% for Latvia, 21.6% for Italy, 17.1% for Belgium, 14.7% for Sweden, 13.7% for Finland, and 13.5% for Germany <ref name="go.bloomberg.com">{{cite news| title = Will Euro Austerity Push the Shadow Economy Even Deeper Into the Dark?| url = http://go.bloomberg.com/market-now/2012/12/06/will-euro-austerity-push-the-shadow-economy-even-deeper-into-the-dark/ |work= Bloomberg | date = 6 December 2012| accessdate= 8 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="Media Coverage">{{cite news |url=https://www.academia.edu/6655991/Media_Coverage_of_the_2010_Greek_Debt_Crisis_Inaccuracies_and_Evidence_of_Manipulation/ |title= Media Coverage of the 2010 Greek Debt Crisis: Inaccuracies and Evidence of Manipulation |work= Academia.edu|date=January 2014 |accessdate= }}</ref> (the situation had improved for Greece, along with most EU countries, by 2017<ref name="Shadow IMF 2017"/>). For Greece, where the percentage of self-employed was more than double the EU average in 2013, a well known pattern is followed, where tax evasion is correlated with the percentage of working population that is self-employed <ref name="Media Coverage"/>.
Several successive Greek governments had in the past attempted to improve the situation. A rapid increase in government revenues through implementing a more effective tax collecting system has been recommended. Implementing the proper reforms, is however estimated to be a slow process, requiring at least two legislative periods before they start to work.<ref name="Fakelaki">{{cite web|title=Griechenland: Abkehr von den Fakelaki|url=http://www.zeit.de/wirtschaft/2010-05/griechenland-korruption-schwarzarbeit?page=all |work=Zeit|date=6 May 2010}}</ref>
In the last quarter of 2005, 49% of the companies inspected by the tax authorities were found to have committed tax offences while in January 2006 it fell to 41.6%.<ref name="Ethnos Forodiafygi" /> A study by researchers from the [[University of Chicago]] concluded that tax evasion in 2009 by self-employed professionals alone in Greece (accountants, dentists, lawyers, doctors, personal tutors and independent financial advisers) was €28 billion or 31% of the budget deficit that year.<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/>
The [[Tax Justice Network]] has said that there are over €20 billion in [[Switzerland|Swiss]] bank accounts held by Greeks.<ref name="Skai TJN">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/182717/20-dis-euro-ehoun-krupsei-oi-ellines-stin-elvetia/ |title=20 δισ. ευρώ έχουν κρύψει οι Έλληνες στην Ελβετία |year=2011 |publisher=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=12 October 2011}}</ref> The former Finance Minister of Greece, Evangelos Venizelos, was quoted as saying "Around 15,000 individuals and companies owe the taxman 37 billion euros".<ref>{{cite news|last=Boyes|first=Roger|title=Rich greeks pack up their troubles along with their euros|accessdate=20 November 2011|newspaper=The Times}}</ref> Additionally, the TJN puts the number of Greek-owned [[Offshore investment|off-shore companies]] to over 10,000.<ref name="Ta Nea TJN">{{cite web |url=http://www.tanea.gr/ellada/article/?aid=4515967 |script-title=el:Υπερδύναμη στις οφ σορ η Ελλάδα |year=2011 |publisher=[[Ta Nea]] |accessdate=12 October 2011|language=el}}</ref>
A mid-2017 report indicated Greeks have been "taxed to the hilt" and many believed that the risk of penalties for tax evasion were less serious than the risk of bankruptcy. One method of evasion is the so-called black market, grey economy or shadow economy: work is done for cash payment which is not declared as income; as well, VAT is not collected and remitted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/18/world/europe/greece-bailout-black-market.html|title=Greeks Turn to the Black Market as Another Bailout Showdown Looms|first=Liz|last=Alderman|date=18 February 2017|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref> A January 2017 report<ref name="auto"/> by the DiaNEOsis think-tank indicated that unpaid taxes in Greece at the time totaled approximately 95 billion euros, up from 76 billion euros in 2015, much of it was expected to be uncollectable. Another early 2017 study estimated that the loss to the government as a result of tax evasion was between 6% and 9% of the country's GDP, or roughly between 11 billion and 16 billion euros per annum.<ref name="keeptalkinggreece.com"/>
The shortfall in the collection of VAT (sales tax) is also significant. In 2014, the government collected 28% less than was owed to it; this shortfall was about double the average for the EU. The uncollected amount that year was about 4.9 billion euros.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-06-23/if-poland-can-fix-tax-fraud-so-can-greece|title=If Poland Can Fix Tax Fraud, So Can Greece|date=23 June 2017|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref> The DiaNEOsis study estimated that 3.5% of GDP is lost due to VAT fraud, while losses due to smuggling of alcohol, tobacco and petrol amounted to approximately another 0.5% of the country's GDP.<ref name="keeptalkinggreece.com"/>
=== Fakelaki === {{Further information|Fakelaki}} In Greek, ''fakelaki'' means "little envelope" but is also used in Greek popular culture as a [[jargon]] term referring to the bribery of public servants and private companies by [[Greece|Greek]] citizens in order to "expedite" service.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenation.com/article/162177/whats-wrong-and-right-about-greece/|title=What's Wrong—and Right—With Greece|work=The Nation|accessdate=20 July 2011}}</ref> According to this practice, sums of money are stuffed in the [[File folder|file]]s and passed across the desk to secure appointments, documents approval and [[License|permits]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.innovationsinnewspapers.com/index.php/2010/02/25/watchdog-journalism-greece-fakelaki-and-the-world-bank/|title=Watchdog Journalism, Greece, "Fakelaki", and the World Bank|work=What's Next: Innovations in Newspapers blog|accessdate=15 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100302204429/http://www.innovationsinnewspapers.com/index.php/2010/02/25/watchdog-journalism-greece-fakelaki-and-the-world-bank/|archivedate=2 March 2010|df=}}</ref> The term was mainly associated with the corruption amongst the doctors of the National Healthcare Service (ESY).
== Government efforts at revenue collection == Following similar actions by the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Germany]], the Greek government is in talks with [[Switzerland]] to tax bank accounts in Switzerland owned by Greek citizens.<ref name="Skai Elvetia">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/184756/mehri-to-telos-tou-2011-i-sumfonia-gia-ti-forologisi-ton-katatheseon-stin-elvetia-/ |script-title=el:Μέχρι το τέλος του 2011 η συμφωνία για τη φορολόγηση των καταθέσεων στην Ελβετία |trans-title=Deal to tax Swiss bank accounts to be reached by end of 2011 |publisher=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=30 October 2011|language=el}}</ref> In late 2011 the [[Minister for Finance (Greece)|Ministry of Finance]] revealed that Greek Swiss bank account holders will either have to pay a tax or reveal information such as the identity of the bank account holder to the Greek internal revenue services.<ref name="Skai Elvetia" /> The Greek and Swiss governments were hoping to reach a deal on the matter by the end of 2011<ref name="Skai Elvetia" /> but that deadline was not met.
Estimates in 2015 indicated that the amount of Greeks' evaded taxes stored in Swiss banks was around 80 billion euros. By then, a tax treaty to address this issue was finally under serious negotiation between the Greek and Swiss governments.<ref>{{cite web|title=Greek minister slams Swiss over tax evasion|url=http://www.thelocal.ch/20150624/greek-minister-slams-swiss-over-tax-evasion|publisher=The Local ch|date=24 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Swiss await Greek input on hidden billions|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/swiss-await-greek-input-on-hidden-billions/41292816|publisher=Swissinfo.ch|date=25 February 2015}}</ref> An agreement was ratified by Switzerland on 1 March 2016 creating a new tax transparency law that would allow for a more effective battle against tax evasion. Starting in 2018, banks in both Greece and Switzerland will exchange information about the bank accounts of citizens of the other country to minimize the possibility of hiding untaxed income.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_MEMO-16-3185_en.htm|title=European Commission - PRESS RELEASES - Press release - EU-Swiss relations|website=europa.eu|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref>
=== Anticorruption measures === The Inspector General of Public Administration<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gedd.gr/ |title=Website of the General inspector of civil services |publisher=Gedd.gr |accessdate=2012-05-16}}</ref> has started an online census of civil servants. In connection with this census he has uncovered a number of offenses.<ref>[http://www.sueddeutsche.de/wirtschaft/griechenland-herkules-versus-verwaltung-1.975855 SZ: Herkules versus Verwaltung], 16 July 2010</ref>{{Citation needed|reason=This claim needs a reliable source. The current reference is to a German newspaper article which gives no support to the alleged incident.|date=May 2018}}
The OECD, the Greek government and the European Commission, developed a project to fight corruption, the National Anti-Corruption Action Plan (NACAP). It was scheduled to operate from October 2016 to December 2017 with some of the funding provided by the European Commission.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/corruption/greece-oecd-anti-corruption.htm|title=Greece-OECD project: Technical support on anti-corruption - OECD|website=www.oecd.org|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> In April 2017, the country's health ministry announced an electronic platform designed to tackle corruption in the healthcare system. Health Minister Andreas Ksanthos made this comment: "We believe that a new culture is needed, another style of the social health system, to convince patients that they can be offered services with dignity without seeking connections with people in charge or financial transactions."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/health-consumers/news/greece-creates-e-platform-to-tackle-corruption-in-healthcare/|title=Greece creates e-platform to tackle corruption in healthcare|website=EURACTIV.com|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref>
=== Tax collection improvements === In 2010 the government has implemented a tax reform. The year 2012 saw the introduction of a duty of non-cash [[payment]]s for amounts over 1,500 euros.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rechtsanwalt-griechenland.de/bekaempfung-der-steuerhinterziehung-in-griechenland.html |title=Maßnahmen zur Bekämpfung der Steuerhinterziehung in Griechenland |publisher=Kosmidis & Partner Anwaltsgesellschaft |date=2010-05-00 |accessdate=28 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://blog.handelsblatt.com/global-reporting/2011/02/11/bargeld-lacht-aber-nicht-mehr-in-griechenland/ |title=Bargeld lacht – aber nicht mehr in Griechenland |newspaper=Handelsblatt Global Reporting |author=[[Gerd Höhler]] |date=11 February 2011 |accessdate=28 October 2011}}</ref>
The Greek police have established a special unit, which deals exclusively with tax offenses. Germany has offered experts from its financial management and tax investigation office to help build a more efficient tax administration.<ref>zeit.de 17. November 2011: [http://www.zeit.de/wirtschaft/2011-11/steuern-griechenland/komplettansicht ''Auf der Jagd nach den reichen Griechen. - Rund 60 Milliarden Euro an Steuern schulden die Griechen dem Staat. Die Regierung in Athen greift nun hart durch, unterstützt von einem Deutschen.'']</ref> However, months later it was not clear whether Greek officials would accept the offer.<ref>reuters.com 19 February 2012: [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/19/us-eurozone-germany-greece-idUSTRE81I0BA20120219 ''Germany urges Greece to accept offers of help'']</ref>
In November 2011, Greek finance minister Evangelos Venizelos called upon all persons who owed the state more than 150,000 euros to pay their outstanding taxes by 24 November or find their names on a black list published on the Internet. The government later revealed the list, which also includes a number of prominent Greeks, including pop stars and sportsmen.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/wirtschaft/macht-die-steuersuender-dingfest/1838898.html |title=Griechenland: "Macht die Steuersünder dingfest!" |author=Gerd Höhler |newspaper=Tagesspiegel |date=15 May 2010 |accessdate=28 October 2011}}</ref> === Forokarta === {{Further information|Forokarta}} The Forokarta is a "tax card" proposed by the government of [[Greece]] in August 2011, which would be used to facilitate collection of receipts for purchases; this would allow the [[Ministry of Finance (Greece)|Greek finance ministry]] to clamp down on rampant tax evasion<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite2_1_05/08/2011_401354|accessdate=24 August 2011|title=New tax system in the pipeline|date=5 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/16792848|accessdate=24 August 2011|title=Tax evasion: Dues and don’ts|date=12 August 2011|work=The Economist}}</ref> by comparing individuals' spending to their income, and by comparing business' ''actual'' revenues to their accounts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athensnews.gr/issue/13455/45874|accessdate=24 August 2011|title=How the state will track your spending|date=7 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321004656/http://www.athensnews.gr/issue/13455/45874|archivedate=21 March 2012|df=}}</ref> As of 2015, this measure is largely defunct and can be considered a failed project.
=== Electronic payments to fight tax avoidance === In 2016 and 2017, the government was encouraging the use of [[credit card]] or [[debit cards]] to pay for goods and services in order to reduce cash only payments. By January 2017, taxpayers were only granted tax-allowances or deductions when payments were made electronically, with a "paper trail" of the transactions that the government could easily audit. This was expected to reduce the problem of businesses taking payments but not issuing an invoice;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tornosnews.gr/en/greek-news/economy/26979-tax-evasion-safari-in-greek-tourist-spots-snags-major-violators.html|title=Tax evasion 'safari' in Greek tourist spots snags major violators - TornosNews.gr|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> that tactic had been used by various companies to avoid payment of VAT (sales) tax as well as income tax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2016/12/13/fin-ministry-bill-gives-tax-breaks-to-greeks-making-payments-with-credit-and-debit-cards/|accessdate=28 August 2017|title=Fin Ministry Bill Gives Tax Breaks to Greeks Making Payments With Credit and Debit Cards|date=13 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2016/0411/Why-Greeks-swap-of-cash-for-cards-could-end-a-culture-of-tax-evasion|accessdate=28 August 2017|title=WORLD EUROPE Why Greeks' swap of cash for cards could end a culture of tax evasion|date=11 April 2016}}</ref>
By 28 July 2017, numerous businesses were required by law to install a [[point of sale]] (POS) device to enable them to accept payment by credit or debit card. Failure to comply with the electronic payment facility can lead to fines of up to 1,500 euros. The requirement applied to around 400,000 firms or individuals in 85 professions. The greater use of electronic payments was one of the factors that had already achieved significant increases in VAT collection in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/220705/article/ekathimerini/business/clear-incentives-for-greater-card-use|title=Clear incentives for greater card use, Nick Malkoutzis - Kathimerini|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref>
== Lagarde list == {{Main article|Lagarde list}} The Greek government has not completed an investigation of a list of 1,991 persons purported to hold accounts with Swiss bank [[HSBC Finance|HSBC]] that it received in 2010 from former French finance minister [[Christine Lagarde]]. Initially, officials claimed at various times to have lost or misplaced the information. On 29 October 2012 the government changed its position saying it would not use stolen information to prosecute suspected offenders. Instead, Greek authorities arrested [[Kostas Vaxevanis]], journalist and editor of the weekly magazine ''[[Hot Doc]]'', who published the "[[Lagarde list]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Λίστα Λαγκάρντ |url=http://www.zougla.gr/politiki/article/lista c|publisher=zougla |date=26 October 2012}}</ref> He was charged for breaching privacy laws that could have seen him sentenced to two years in prison.<ref>{{cite news|title=Greek officials accused of persecution as 'Lagarde List' journalist appears in court |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/greece/9641410/Greek-officials-accused-of-persecution-as-Lagarde-List-journalist-appears-in-court.html |publisher=The Telegraph| date=30 October 2012|location=London|first=Damien|last=McElroy}}</ref> However, after a trial lasting only a day, he was acquitted.<ref>{{cite news|title=Greek bank list editor Costas Vaxevanis acquitted |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20172516 |publisher=BBC News| date=1 November 2012}}</ref> Another trial, in 2015 found the former minister of economy [[:el:Γεώργιος Παπακωνσταντίνου|Giorgos Papakonstantinou]] guilty for document distortion.<ref>[http://www.tovima.gr/society/article/?aid=688805 A year in jail for Langarde list at Giorgos Papakonstantinou] Το Βήμα 24 March 2015</ref>
The list includes an advisor to former Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras, as well as a former minister and a member of Samaras' New Democracy political party. The list also contains the names of officials in the finance ministry.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Controversial 'Lagarde List' Has Leaked, And It's Bad News For The Greek Prime Minister |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/lagarde-list-of-swiss-bank-accounts-leaked-2012-10 |publisher=Business Insider| date=27 October 2012}}</ref>
Mr Vaxevanis said he thought the government had not acted on the list because it included friends of ministers, businessmen and powerful publishers.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">Mark Lowen, [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20163430 Greek journalist Costas Vaxevanis on trial over bank list], BBC News, November 1, 2012</ref> He also accused much of the Greek media of ignoring the story.<ref name="bbc.co.uk" /> "The Greek press is muzzled", he said. "There is a closed system of power in Greece, wielded by the political elite, businessmen and journalists."<ref name="bbc.co.uk" />

revision.text:
{{Culture of Gibraltar}} This article is about the '''[[demographics|demographic]] features of the [[population]] of [[Gibraltar]]''', including [[ethnic group|ethnicity]], education level, health of the populace, economic status, religious affiliations and other aspects of the population.
==Ethnic origins== One of the main features of Gibraltar’s population is the diversity of their [[ethnic group|ethnic origins]]. The demographics of Gibraltar reflects Gibraltarians' [[Culture of Gibraltar|racial and cultural fusion]] of the many [[European ethnic groups|European]] and non-European immigrants who came to the [[Rock of Gibraltar|Rock]] over three hundred years. They are the descendants of economic migrants that came to Gibraltar after the majority of the Spanish population left in 1704.
===Spanish=== The majority of the Spanish population in Gibraltar (about 5000), with few exceptions, left Gibraltar when the Dutch and English took the village in 1704. The few [[Spaniard]]s who remained in Gibraltar in August 1704 were augmented by others who arrived in the fleet with [[Prince George of Hesse-Darmstadt]], possibly some two hundred in all, mostly [[Catalan people|Catalans]].<ref>[http://www.iteg.org/documentos/spaniards_in_gibraltar.pdf Spaniards in Gibraltar] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060304033327/http://www.iteg.org/documentos/spaniards_in_gibraltar.pdf |date=2006-03-04 }}</ref>
[[Menorca|Menorcans]] are a small and interesting group. Their migration to Gibraltar started since the beginning of the common British rule in 1713, thanks to the links between both British possessions during the 18th century, first looking for work in several trades, especially when Gibraltar needed to be rebuilt after the 1783 Grand Siege. Immigration continued even after Menorca (the original English name was "Minorca") was returned to Spain in 1802 by the [[Treaty of Amiens]].<ref>{{cite book |first=William |last=Jackson |year=1990 |title=The Rock of the Gibraltarians. A History of Gibraltar |publisher=Gibraltar Books | edition = second |location=Grendon, Northamptonshire, UK |isbn=0-948466-14-6 | page=225}}: "The open frontier helped to increase the Spanish share, and naval links with Minorca produced the small Minorcan contingent."</ref><ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2ip0C6odET4C | title=Gibraltar, identity and empire | author=Edward G. Archer | publisher=Routledge | year=2006 | isbn=978-0-415-34796-9 | pages=42–43}}</ref>
[[Immigration]] from Spain (like the exiles from the Spanish Civil War) and intermarriage with [[Andalusian people|Spaniards]] from the [[Campo de Gibraltar|surrounding Spanish towns]] was a constant feature of [[History of Gibraltar|Gibraltar's history]] until the then Spanish [[dictator]], General [[Francisco Franco]], closed the border with Gibraltar in 1969, cutting off many Gibraltarians from their relatives on the Spanish side of the frontier.
Together, Gibraltarians of [[Spanish people|Spanish]] origin are one of the bigger groups (more than 24% according to last names, even more taking into account the fact that many Spanish women married native Gibraltarians).<ref>Archer, Edward G.: [https://books.google.com/books?id=2ip0C6odET4C&pg=PP1 ''Gibraltar, identity and empire''], page 43. Routledge Advances in European Politics.</ref>
===British=== [[British people|Britons]] have come and settled or gone since the first days of the conquest. One group of Britons have had temporary residence in Gibraltar (to work in the administration and the garrison). This group, who represented a larger proportion in the beginning of the British period, are nowadays only about 3% of the total population (around 1,000 persons).
A larger group is formed by the Britons who moved to Gibraltar and settled down. Some of them, since the beginning, moved to Gibraltar to earn a living as traders and workers. Others moved to Gibraltar on a temporary assignment and then married with local women. Major construction projects, such as the dockyard in the late 1890s and early 20th century brought large numbers of workers from Great Britain.
13% of Gibraltarian residents are from the United Kingdom proper and the electoral roll shows that 27% of Gibraltar's population has British surnames.<ref>Archer, Edward G.: [https://books.google.com/books?id=2ip0C6odET4C&pg=PP1&dq=archer+identity+empire+gibraltar&ei=F2SrSsKWA6nEzgSMnfGsCg#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Gibraltar, identity and empire''], page 40. Routledge Advances in European Politics.</ref>
===Genoese and other Italians=== [[Genoa|Genoese]] came during the 18th and 19th centuries, especially from the poorer parts of [[Liguria]], some of them annually following fishing shoals, as repairmen for the [[Royal Navy|British navy]], or as successful traders and merchants;<ref>Archer, Edward G.: [https://books.google.com/books?id=2ip0C6odET4C&pg=PP1&dq=archer+identity+empire+gibraltar&ei=F2SrSsKWA6nEzgSMnfGsCg#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Gibraltar, identity and empire''], page 37. Routledge Advances in European Politics.</ref> many others came during the Napoleonic period to avoid obligatory conscription to the French Army.<ref name="google24">Levey, David: [https://books.google.com/books?id=VKW6uqxsj4YC&pg=PA24&dq=french+gibraltar+ethnic&ei=nGOrSqv8OaSCywSMtvilCg#v=onepage&q=french%20gibraltar%20ethnic&f=false ''Language change and variation in Gibraltar'', page 24. John Benjamins Publishing Company.]</ref> Genoese formed the larger group of the new population in the 18th century and middle 19th century. Other [[Italians]] came from islands like [[Sardinia]] and [[Sicily]]. Nowadays, people with Genoese/Italian last names represent about 20% of the population.
===Portuguese=== [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] were one of the earliest groups to move to Gibraltar, especially from the [[Algarve]] region in the far south of [[Portugal]]. Most of them went to work as labourers and some as traders. Their number increased significantly during the 18th century, and again when many Spaniards left their jobs in Gibraltar after General Franco closed the border in 1969. About 10% of last names in Gibraltar have Portuguese origin.<ref>Archer, Edward G.: [https://books.google.com/books?id=2ip0C6odET4C&pg=PP1&dq=archer+identity+empire+gibraltar&ei=F2SrSsKWA6nEzgSMnfGsCg#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Gibraltar, identity and empire''], page 41. Routledge Advances in European Politics.</ref>
===Moroccans=== [[Moroccan people|Moroccans]] have always had a significant presence in Gibraltar. However, the modern community has more recent origins. Moroccans began arriving in Gibraltar soon after the Spanish government imposed the first restrictions on Spanish workers in Gibraltar in 1964. By the end of 1968 there were at least 1,300 Moroccan workers resident in Gibraltar and this more than doubled following the final closure of the frontier with Spain in June 1969.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sussex.ac.uk/migration/documents/briefing3.pdf|title=Sussex Migration Briefing - Steps to resolving the situation of Moroccans in Gibraltar|publisher=}}</ref> There is also a significant amount of [[Moroccan Jews]] in Gibraltar, representing Jews of both [[Sephardic]] origin and Arabic speaking Jews of Morocco (although almost no Gibraltarian Jews today speak Arabic as a first language). Most notably the [[Hassan (surname)|Hassan]] family which runs Gibraltar's largest law firm [[Hassans|Hassans International Law Firm]]<ref>Legal 500, 2009</ref> and the late [[Joshua Hassan|Sir Joshua Hassan]] who served four terms as Chief Minister for a total of 17 years.<ref name="independent">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-sir-joshua-hassan-1248542.html |title=Obituary: Sir Joshua Hassan |accessdate=23 November 2009 |last=Nash |first=Elizabeth |date=2 July 1997 |work=The Independent |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5lV0KbHCi?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-sir-joshua-hassan-1248542.html |archivedate=23 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Other groups=== Other groups include: *[[Maltese people|Maltese]] were in the same imperial route to the east as Gibraltar. They came when jobs were scarce at home and others to escape the law in [[Malta]].<ref>Archer, Edward G.: [https://books.google.com/books?id=2ip0C6odET4C&pg=PP1&dq=archer+identity+empire+gibraltar&ei=F2SrSsKWA6nEzgSMnfGsCg#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Gibraltar, identity and empire''], page 44. Routledge Advances in European Politics.</ref> *[[Jew]]s, most of them of [[Sephardi Jews|Sephardi]] origin, were able to re-establish their rites, [[Alhambra decree|forbidden in Catholic Spain]], right after the British occupation in 1704. Also a significant number of Jews from London settled in Gibraltar, especially since the [[Great Siege of Gibraltar|Great Siege]].<ref>Archer, Edward G.: [https://books.google.com/books?id=2ip0C6odET4C&pg=PP1&dq=archer+identity+empire+gibraltar&ei=F2SrSsKWA6nEzgSMnfGsCg#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Gibraltar, identity and empire''], page 38. Routledge Advances in European Politics.</ref> *[[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|Indians]], came as merchants after the opening of the [[Suez Canal]] in 1870; many others migrated as workers after the closure of the frontier with Spain in 1969 to replace Spanish ones.<ref>Archer, Edward G.: [https://books.google.com/books?id=2ip0C6odET4C&pg=PP1&dq=archer+identity+empire+gibraltar&ei=F2SrSsKWA6nEzgSMnfGsCg#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Gibraltar, identity and empire''], page 45. Routledge Advances in European Politics.</ref> *[[French people|French]], many of whom came after the French Revolution in 1789, set up trade and commerce.<ref name="google24"/> *[[Austrians]], [[Chinese people|Chinese]], [[Japanese people|Japanese]], [[Polish people|Polish]] or [[Danes]].
== 2012 census<ref>[http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/new/sites/default/files/HMGoG_Documents/Full_Census_Report_2012.pdf#page=63]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/new/full-census-report-2012|title=Full Census Report 2012 - Government of Gibraltar|website=www.gibraltar.gov.gi}}</ref> ==

== Population overview ==
[[File:Gibraltar population (1725-2001).png|thumb|500px|Civilian population in Gibraltar according to the censuses from 1725 to 2001]] The population of Gibraltar was 29,752 in 2011.<ref>[http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/images/stories/PDF/statistics/Key_Indicators_Website.pdf]</ref>

== CIA World Factbook demographic statistics ==
The following demographic statistics are from the [[CIA World Factbook]], unless otherwise indicated.
===Population age=== ''0-14 years:'' 17.2% (male 2,460; female 2,343) <br />''15-64 years:'' 66.3% (male 9,470; female 9,070) <br />''65 years and over:'' 16.5% (male 2,090; female 2,534) (2007 est.)<ref name=INT>[http://www.intute.ac.uk/sciences/worldguide/html/893_people.html Intute World Guide - Gibraltar.]</ref>
===Sex ratio=== ''At birth:'' 1.06 males/female <br />''0-14 years:'' 1.05 males/female <br />''15-64 years:'' 1.044 males/female <br />''65 years and over:'' 0.825 males/female <br />''total population:'' 1.005 males/female (2007 est.)<ref name=INT/>
The median age is: <br />total: 40.3 years <br />male: 39.8 years <br />female: 40.7 years (2008 est.)<ref name=INT/>
===Life expectancy=== ''total population:'' 79.93 years <br />''male:'' 77.05 years <br />''female:'' 82.96 years (2007 est.)<ref name=INT/>
===Fertility=== 1.95 children born/woman (2007 est.)<ref name=INT/>
===Infant mortality=== ''total:'' <br />4.98 deaths/1,000 live births ''male:'' <br />5.54 deaths/1,000 live births ''female:'' <br />4.39 deaths/1,000 live births (2007 est.)<ref name=INT/>
===Nationality=== ''noun:'' Gibraltarian(s) <br />''adjective:'' Gibraltar
===Religions=== {{outdated section|date=January 2016}} [[Roman Catholic]] 78.09%, [[Church of England]] 6.98%, Other [[Christian]] 3.21%, [[Muslim]] 4.01%, [[Jewish]] 2.12%, [[Hindu]] 1.79%, other or unspecified 0.94%, none 2.86% (2001 census)<ref name=CEN/>
===Languages=== [[English language|English]] (used in schools and for official purposes), [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. Most Gibraltarians converse in ''[[Llanito]]'', an [[Andalusian Spanish]] based [[vernacular]]. It consists of an eclectic mix of Andalusian Spanish and [[British English]] as well as languages such as [[Maltese language|Maltese]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Italian language|Italian]] of the [[Genoese dialect|Genoese]] variety and [[Haketia]]. Among more educated Gibraltarians, it also typically involves [[code-switching]] to English. [[Arabic language|Arabic]] is spoken by the Moroccan community, just like [[Hindi]] and [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] is spoken by the Indian community of Gibraltar. [[Maltese language|Maltese]] is still spoken by some families of Maltese descent.
===Literacy=== ''definition:'' NA <br />''total population:'' above 80% <br />''male:'' NA% <br />''female:'' NA%
==Educational attainment in Gibraltar==
{| class="wikitable" ! Rank !! Religion !! Proportion (%) of pupils<br />achieving 5 or more<br />[[GCSE]]'s (Grades A-C) |- | 1 || Hindu || 79% |- | 2 || Jewish || 76% |- | 3 || All other religions || 68% |- | 4 || National average || 66% |- | 5 || Christian || 66% |- | 6 || None || 64% |- | 7 || Muslim || 44% |}

Percentage of people of<br />working age with a [[Academic degree|degree]] |- | 1 || Indian || 71% |- | 2 || British || 26% |- | 3 || Other EU || 24% |- | 4 || All other national origins || 24% |- | 5 || National average || 23% |- | 6 || Gibraltarian || 23% |- | 7 || Spanish || 16% |- | 8 || Moroccan || 14% |}
==Crime rate== {| class="wikitable" |+Total crimes (per capita) by national origin !National origin !Total crimes (per capita) |- | Moroccan | 9.4 per 100 people |- | Gibraltarian | 6.3 per 100 people |- | UK British | 6.3 per 100 people |- | National average | 6.3 per 100 people |- | Other EU | 5.8 per 100 people |- | Other national origins | 5.4 per 100 people |- | Indian | 1.6 per 100 people |}
A total of 2,093 [[criminal offence]]s were recorded in Gibraltar during 2005/2006. Indians had a significantly lower crime rate in 2005/2006 than all other national origins in Gibraltar at 1.69 crimes per 100 Indian people. The crimes per 100 population in Gibraltar now stands at 6.3. The crime rate for Gibraltarians and Moroccans has risen from 6.1 and 9.36 per 100 people in 2004/2005 to its current levels.

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Drag Me to Hell | image = Dragmetohell.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Sam Raimi]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Robert Tapert]] * [[Grant Curtis]] }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * Sam Raimi * [[Ivan Raimi]] }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Alison Lohman]] * [[Justin Long]] * [[Lorna Raver]] * [[Dileep Rao]] * [[David Paymer]] * [[Adriana Barraza]] }} | music = [[Christopher Young]] | cinematography = [[Peter Deming]] | editing = [[Bob Murawski]] | studio = [[Ghost House Pictures]] | distributor = [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2009|03|15|[[South by Southwest|SXSW]]|2009|05|29|United States}} | runtime = 99 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 98:49--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/drag-me-hell-2009-0 | title=''DRAG ME TO HELL'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=May 8, 2009 | accessdate=January 9, 2016}}</ref> | country = United States | language = {{Plainlist| * English * Spanish }} | budget = $30 million<ref name="boxofficemojo"/> | gross = $90.8 million<ref name="boxofficemojo"/> }} '''''Drag Me to Hell''''' is a 2009 American [[supernatural horror film]] co-written and directed by [[Sam Raimi]]. The plot, written with his older brother [[Ivan Raimi|Ivan]], focuses on a loan officer, who, because she has to prove to her boss that she can make the "hard decisions", chooses not to extend an elderly woman's mortgage. In retaliation, the woman places a [[curse]] on the loan officer that, after three days of escalating torment, will plunge her into the depths of [[Hell]] to burn for eternity.
Raimi wrote ''Drag Me to Hell'' with his brother, Ivan, before working on the [[Spider-Man in film#Sam Raimi films|''Spider-Man'' trilogy]]. The film premiered at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] and was released to critical acclaim. It was also a box office success, grossing over $90 million worldwide. ''Drag Me to Hell'' won the award for [[Saturn Award for Best Horror Film|Best Horror Film]] at the 2009 [[Scream Awards]] and the 2010 [[Saturn Awards]].
==Plot== In 1969, in [[Pasadena]], a couple seeks the aid of the [[mediumship|medium]] Shaun San Dena, saying their son has been hearing evil spirits' voices after stealing a silver necklace from a "gypsy wagon". San Dena aids the family by carrying out a [[séance]], but they are attacked by an unseen force that drags the boy to [[Hell]].
In present-day [[Los Angeles]], bank loan officer Christine is in competition for a promotion with Stu Rubin. Her boss advises her to demonstrate that she can make tough decisions. An elderly woman, Sylvia Ganush, asks for a third extension on her mortgage payment, and despite Ganush's financial and medical problems, Christine denies her an extension to prove herself. Ganush begs Christine not to repossess her house. Ganush is taken away, accusing Christine of "shaming" her and swears revenge.
In the parking garage Christine is ambushed by Ganush, who is hiding in the back seat. Ganush rips a button from Christine's coat and intones words in another language. Later, Christine and her boyfriend Clay meet [[fortune teller]] Rham Jas, who tells Christine that she is being haunted by a dark spirit, likely the result of a [[curse]]. At home, Christine is attacked by the entity and has nightmares about Ganush. At work the next day, she hallucinates and bleeds profusely from her nose. She leaves the office, and, amid the general panic, Stu steals a file from Christine's desk.
Christine goes to beg Ganush for forgiveness but discovers that Ganush has died. Christine returns to Jas, who explains that as long as Christine is the owner of an accursed object (the button), she will be haunted by a powerful demon called the "Lamia". It will torment her for three days before taking her to Hell. He suggests a sacrifice to appease it. Christine reluctantly sacrifices her pet kitten. She meets Clay’s parents at their house for dinner, where she is again tormented by the Lamia, plagued with grotesque hallucinations.
Christine returns to Jas, who requests a fee of $10,000. He introduces her to San Dena who prepares a séance to trap the Lamia's spirit in a goat and kill it, but things go wrong and the Lamia inhabits first her body and then her assistant Milos. San Dena excorcises the Lamia, but dies from the effort. Jas explains that the plan failed. He seals the button in an envelope and tells Christine that she can be rid of the curse by giving the button to someone else, thereby passing the curse on to that person. Christine decides to give the envelope to Stu, but changes her mind. Jas advises Christine that she can give the button to a dead person. Christine digs up Ganush's grave, and "formally" gifts her the button after some struggle, just before dawn.
Christine returns home and prepares to meet Clay at [[Union Station (Los Angeles)|Los Angeles Union Station]] for a weekend trip. She gets a message from her boss telling her that she landed her dream position after Stu confessed to stealing her work and was fired. Clay reveals to her that he found the envelope containing the cursed button in his car. She realizes that the envelope was mistaken for the other and that the curse was never lifted. Horrified, Christine backs away and falls onto the tracks. As Clay looks on, unable to reach her, a train barrels towards her, just as fiery hands emerge from the tracks and drag Christine into Hell. Clay, holding the button in his hand at the edge of the train platform stares horrified at the tracks.
==Cast== [[File:Drag Me to Hell ComicCon panel.jpg|right|thumb|Director Sam Raimi, actors Dileep Rao, Alison Lohman, and Justin Long discussing the film at [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] in 2008.]] * [[Alison Lohman]] as Christine Brown: A young mild-mannered bank employee who desires the position of assistant manager. After turning down Sylvia Ganush's request for a third extension on her mortgage, she is cursed by her and attacked by a demon called the Lamia. * [[Justin Long]] as Professor Clayton "Clay" Dalton: Christine's boyfriend who is a college professor born to a wealthy family. Clayton is skeptical about Rham Jas's help and the existence of the demon. * [[Lorna Raver]] as Mrs. Sylvia Ganush: An elderly gypsy Hungarian woman who attacks Christine Brown and places a curse on her. Ganush dies the day after the attack, but her soul constantly haunts Christine throughout the film. * [[Dileep Rao]] as Rham Jas: A young psychic who informs Christine that she is cursed. Rham Jas later introduces Christine to Shaun San Dena who has a seance with her. * [[David Paymer]] as Mr. Jim Jacks: Christine's concerned boss who is considering whether Christine or Stu Rubin deserves the job of assistant manager at the bank. * [[Adriana Barraza]] as Shaun San Dena: A psychic who has a seance to draw out the Lamia to kill it for Christine. ** Flor de Maria Chahua as young Shaun San Dena * [[Bojana Novakovic]] as Ilenka Ganush: Sylvia Ganush's cynical granddaughter. She lets Christine into her home when she asks to meet the elderly Ganush. * [[Reggie Lee (actor)|Reggie Lee]] as Stu Rubin: A conniving employee of the bank Christine works at. Stu tries to make Christine look bad at work in order to get the promotion. * [[Chelcie Ross]] as Leonard Dalton: Clay's father who does not approve of Clayton dating Christine. * [[Molly Cheek]] as Trudy Dalton: Clay's mother who also does not approve of Clayton dating Christine due to her "[[peasant]]" origin and bizarre behavior (which was caused by the Lamia). * Art Kimbro as the voice of the Lamia: A powerful demon that is summoned after Ganush curses Christine. Its task is to torment Christine for three days before literally dragging her into Hell to burn for eternity. * [[Octavia Spencer]] as bank co-worker * [[Alex Veadov]] as the man with ponytail at the death feast
The film includes [[cameo appearance]]s by Raimi himself as an uncredited ghost at the seance, Raimi's younger brother [[Ted Raimi|Ted]] as a doctor, members of Raimi's family Emma, Henry, and Lorne in minor roles, frequent Raimi collaborator [[Scott Spiegel]] as a mourner at the death feast, and [[John Paxton]] and Irene Roseen as the old couple at the diner.
==Production==
===Background=== The original story for ''Drag Me to Hell'' was written ten years before the film went into production and was written by [[Sam Raimi]] and his brother [[Ivan Raimi]]. The film went into production under the name ''The Curse''.<ref name="prod">{{cite web | title = Drag Me to Hell Production Notes | url = http://www.dragmetohell.net/assets/production/production_notes.html | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090519202048/http://www.dragmetohell.net/assets/production/production_notes.html | archivedate = May 19, 2009 | work = Drag Me To Hell Official Website | publisher = [[Universal Pictures]] | location = Los Angeles, California | year = 2009 | accessdate = 2009-06-27}}</ref> The Raimis wrote the script as a [[morality tale]], desiring to write a story about a character who wants to be a good person, but makes a sinful choice out of greed for her own betterment and pays the price for it.<ref name="festival-cannes">{{cite web | title = ''Drag Me to Hell'' : Cannes Press Conference (8:00) | url = http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/mediaPlayer/10041.html | work = [[Cannes Film Festival]] | format = Video | year = 2009 | accessdate = 2009-06-27}}</ref> The Raimis tried to make the character of Christine the main focal point in the film, and tried to have Christine in almost all the scenes in the film.<ref name="prod" /> Elements of the film's story are drawn from the [[British cinema|British]] [[horror film]] ''[[Night of the Demon]]'' (itself an adaptation of [[M.R. James]]' short story "[[Casting the Runes]]") such as the similar-shaped demons and the three-day curse theme in the film.<ref>{{cite web | title = Movie Review: Drag Me to Hell : Mountain Xpress | url = http://www.mountainx.com/movies/review/drag_me_to_hell | first = Ken | last = Hanke | date = 2009-06-03 | work = [[Mountain Xpress]] | accessdate = 2009-06-27}}</ref><ref name="variety" /> The most significant parallel is that both stories involve the passing of a cursed object, which has to be passed to someone else, or its possessor will be devoured by one or more demons. Unlike his past horror films, Raimi wanted the film to be rated PG-13 and not strictly driven by gore, stating, "I didn't want to do exactly the same thing I had done before."<ref name="prod" /><ref name="15cannes">{{cite web | title = ''Drag Me to Hell'' : Cannes Press Conference (15:30) | url = http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/mediaPlayer/10041.html | work = [[Cannes Film Festival]] | format = Video | year = 2009 | accessdate = 2009-06-27}}</ref>
After finishing the script, Raimi desired to make the picture after the first draft of the script was completed, but other projects such as the [[Spider-Man in film|''Spider-Man'' film series]] became a nearly decade-long endeavor, pushing opportunities to continue work on ''Drag Me to Hell'' to late 2007.<ref name="prod" /> Raimi offered director [[Edgar Wright]] to direct ''Drag Me to Hell'' which Wright turned down as he was filming ''[[Hot Fuzz]]'' and felt that "If I did it, it would just feel like karaoke."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/latest/305032-hero_worship_sam_raimi|work=[[The Skinny (magazine)|The Skinny]]|title=Hero Worship: Sam Raimi|author=Wright, Edgar|authorlink=Edgar Wright|accessdate=July 8, 2013|date=July 8, 2013}}</ref> After the previous three ''Spider-Man'' films, Raimi came back to the script of ''Drag Me to Hell'', wanting to make a simpler and lower-budget film.<ref name="CannesInterview">{{cite web | title = ''Drag Me to Hell'' : Cannes Interview | url = http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/mediaPlayer/10040.html | work = [[Cannes Film Festival]] | format = Video | year = 2009 | accessdate = 2009-06-27}}</ref> In 2007, Sam Raimi's friend and [[Film producer|producer]] [[Robert Tapert]] of [[Ghost House Pictures]] had the company sign on to finance the film.<ref name="prod" /> [[Universal Studios]] agreed to distribute domestically.<ref name="prod" />
===Casting=== After completing the script and having the project greenlit, Raimi started casting the film.<ref name="prod" /> [[Ellen Page]] was originally cast for the main role of Christine, but dropped out of the project due to [[Screen Actors Guild#2008–09 Screen Actors Guild labor dispute|SAG strike]]-related scheduling issues.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.movieweb.com/news/NElPVqonXe3xpl | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110611043502/http://www.movieweb.com/news/ellen-page-quits-sam-raimis-drag-me-to-hell | archivedate = June 11, 2011 | title = Ellen Page Quits Sam Raimi's ''Drag Me to Hell'' | date = February 29, 2008 | publisher = MovieWeb | quote = We were racing to start production so that we could accommodate Ellen's schedule. But like so many other productions trying to start before the potential SAG strike date, this one needed more time and we had to push back the start of production.}}</ref> The main role eventually went to Lohman, who didn't enjoy [[horror film]]s, but enjoyed doing the stunts during filming.<ref name="prod" /> Stage actress [[Lorna Raver]] auditioned for the role of Mrs. Ganush. Raver was not aware of the specific nature of her character until being cast, stating that all she had read was "about a little old lady coming into the bank because they're closing down her house. It was only later that I saw the whole script and said, 'Oh my!'"<ref name="prod" /> To prepare for this role, Raver met with a Hungarian dialect coach and asked to have portions of the script translated into Hungarian.<ref name="prod" /> Raimi would later ask Raver to use some of the Hungarian words in the scenes of Ganush's attacking Christine.<ref name="prod" /> [[Dileep Rao]], who plays Rham Jas, made producer [[Grant Curtis]] mildly hesitant in casting him, stating that during his audition "he was a little bit younger than he read in the script. But as we were looking at his reading, Sam said, 'There's no minimum age requirement on wisdom.' Dileep has that wisdom and presence on screen, and that’s what made him right. Once he got on camera, he brought that shoulder for Alison to lean on."<ref name="prod" /> Many of the actors playing secondary characters in ''Drag Me to Hell'' have appeared previously in Raimi's films, including Joanne Baron, Tom Carey, [[Molly Cheek]], Aimee Miles, John Paxton, [[Ted Raimi]], Bill E. Rogers, [[Chelcie Ross]], and [[Octavia Spencer]].<ref name="prod" />
===Filming=== Raimi said he set out to create “a horror film with lots of wild moments and lots of suspense and big shocks that’ll hopefully make audiences jump. But I also wanted to have a lot of dark humor sprinkled throughout. I spent the last decade doing ''[[Spider-Man (2002 film)|Spider-Man]]'' and you come to rely on a lot of people doing things for you and a lot of help, but it’s refreshing and wonderful to be reminded that, as with most filmmakers, the best way to do it is yourself, with a tight team doing the main jobs."<ref name="PostMag">{{cite web | last = Blair | first = Iain | title = Director's Chair: Sam Raimi Drag me to Hell | url = http://www.postmagazine.com/ME2/dirmod.asp?tier=4&mid=8F3A7027421841978F18BE895F87F791&sid=&nm=&id=9A2AE6F97AE946859A3C884BDE603E22&type=Publishing&mod=Publications%3A%3AArticle | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802031958/http://www.postmagazine.com/ME2/dirmod.asp?sid=&nm=&type=Publishing&mod=Publications%3A%3AArticle&mid=8F3A7027421841978F18BE895F87F791&tier=4&id=9A2AE6F97AE946859A3C884BDE603E22 | archivedate=August 2, 2009 | work = Post Magazine | date = July 1, 2009 | accessdate = July 9, 2013}}</ref>
Production for ''Drag Me to Hell'' began on location in [[Tarzana, Los Angeles|Tarzana, California]].<ref name="prod" /> The production team included director of photography [[Peter Deming]] (''[[Evil Dead II]]'', ''[[Mulholland Drive (film)|Mulholland Dr.]]''), production designer Steve Saklad (''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]''), and visual effects supervisor Bruce Jones. The film was produced by [[Grant Curtis]] and [[Rob Tapert]]. Tapert and Raimi are longtime collaborators, having attended college together in Michigan.<ref name="PostMag" />
===Editing=== ''Drag Me to Hell'' was edited by [[Bob Murawski]], who has collaborated with Raimi on several films including the ''[[Spider-Man (2002 film)|Spider-Man]]'' series, ''[[The Gift (2000 film)|The Gift]]'', and ''[[Army of Darkness]]''.<ref name="PostMag" />
Raimi has said of working with Murawski on ''Drag Me to Hell'', "He’d come (down to the set) to see how things were going and to let me know if he’d just cut something that wasn’t working the way he’d wanted it to, or to suggest a pick-up shot I should get for a piece he felt we needed in a sequence I hadn’t realized I needed. He’s very detail-oriented... So we’re very close collaborators."
Raimi finds editing with Murawski to be "relaxing", adding, "I love it. For me, it's so relaxing, unlike pre-production, which is fraught with anxiety and fear about how we'e going to do things, and production, which is so rushed and a sleepless time and you're just racing to finish every shot and worrying about focus and so on. So post is soothing and I can watch the film come together, so it's a time of discovery for me as Bob and I fit all the pieces together. I see new possibilities in post, as Bob puts the film together, sometimes in a way I never imagined..."<ref name="PostMag" />
The film was edited by Murawski on an Avid computer system in a West Los Angeles facility. The color grading was completed at Company 3 with colorist Stephen Nakamura. Nakamura used DaVinci Resolve. It was CO3's first start-to-finish feature in 4K resolution.<ref name="PostMag" />
"For us, post is a very creative time where it's not just about this factory producing the blueprinted product. It's really a very creative, experimental time where we try and take everything that's been written and then shot to the next level," said Raimi.<ref name="PostMag" />
The final sound mix was completed at the Dub Stage in Burbank with mixers Marti Humphrey and Chris Jacobson.<ref name="PostMag" />
===Effects=== The effects in ''Drag Me to Hell'' were created in many different ways, including [[Chroma key|green screen]], [[puppet]]s, prosthetics and [[computer-generated imagery]].<ref name="prod" /> Bruce Jones was the visual effects supervisor on the film. Of Jones, Raimi commented, "He brought a great can-do approach to the film... He's got a great team of artists and technicians with him, and he's got great instincts."<ref name="PostMag" />
There were hundreds of visual effects in the film, and different effects houses were utilized. According to Raimi, the [[Bay Area]]'s Tippett Studio was a big player. "We also had work done by Amalgamated Pixels, Ghost VFX, KNB Effects, Home Digital, Cinesoup and IE Effects," said Raimi. According to Raimi, “Bob (Murawski) and I kept adding visual effects as post proceeded. In this film, the supernatural, the unseen, is almost another character, so sequences were developed — even in post — that would suggest the presence of the supernatural, and we kept on adding. The same with the sound effects, so it was a very ongoing, very live process in post."<ref name="PostMag" />
Director of photography [[Peter Deming]] tried to use realistic lighting in the film. Said Deming, "Normally, you'd put all corrected bulbs in, but we went with what was there, including the shots in the street. We used the streetlight look and mixed that with interior lighting. There were a lot of odd color sources that we chose to leave the way they would be naturally. It's a heightened sense of realism."<ref name="prod" /> One of the earliest projects the special effects teams did was the scene in which Mrs. Ganush attacks Christine in her car. To film the action, which included close-ups of Christine jamming her foot on the pedal, hitting the brake, and shifting gears, the team created a puzzle car which allowed the front engine compartment and back trunk — as well as all four sides and doors — to come away from the car. The roof came off in two directions.<ref name="prod" />
===Soundtrack=== {{Infobox album | name = Drag Me to Hell | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Christopher Young]] | cover = | alt = | released = August 18, 2009 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Film score]] | length = 52:27 | label = | producer = Brian McNelis, Flavio Motalla, [[Skip Williamson (producer)|Skip Williamson]], [[Christopher Young]]<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1575235|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=November 24, 2009|title=Drag Me to Hell: Credits}}</ref> | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Album ratings |rev1=[[AllMusic]] |rev1score={{rating|3.5|5}}<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1575235|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=November 24, 2009|title=Drag Me to Hell: Overview}}</ref> |rev2=[[Soundtrack.Net]] |rev2score={{rating|3.5|5}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Drag Me to Hell|url=http://www.soundtrack.net/album/drag-me-to-hell/|publisher=[[Soundtrack.Net]]|accessdate=9 March 2017}}</ref> }} The [[film score]] was composed by [[Christopher Young]]. Young has worked with director Raimi previously on his films ''[[The Gift (2000 film)|The Gift]]'' and ''[[Spider-Man 3]]''. The soundtrack was released on August 18, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangoria.com/musick/musick-news/3602-drag-me-to-hell-soundtrack-hits-stores.html|work=[[Fangoria]]|accessdate=November 24, 2009|date=August 17, 2009|author=Zimmerman, Samuel|title=Drag Me to Hell soundtrack hits stores}}</ref> Sam Raimi stated that emphasis was on using the soundtrack to create a world that didn't exist, a world of the "supernatural".<ref name="PostMag" /> The score contains elements of Young's previous work on ''[[Flowers in the Attic (film)|Flowers in the Attic]]''. This is particularly apparent in the utilization of the ethereal childlike soprano vocals that feature prominently throughout the soundtrack.
All tracks composed by Christopher Young.
{{Track listing | headline = ''Drag Me to Hell (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)'' | total_length = 52:25 | title1 = Drag Me to Hell | length1 = 2:32 | title2 = Mexican Devil Disaster | length2 = 4:33 | title3 = Tale of a Haunted Banker | length3 = 1:52 | title4 = Lamia | length4 = 4:06 | title5 = Black Rainbows | length5 = 3:24 | title6 = Ode to Ganush | length6 = 2:23 | title7 = Familiar Familiars | length7 = 2:11 | title8 = Loose Teeth | length8 = 6:31 | title9 = Ordeal by Corpse | length9 = 4:35 | title10 = Bealing Bells with Trumpet | length10 = 5:12 | title11 = Brick Dogs Ala Carte | length11 = 1:46 | title12 = Muttled Buttled Brain Stew | length12 = 2:51 | title13 = Auto-Da-Fe | length13 = 4:31 | title14 = Concerto to Hell | length14 = 5:58 }}
==Release== ''Drag Me to Hell'' was first shown to the public as a "Work in Progress" print at the [[South by Southwest]] festival on March 15, 2009.<ref>{{cite web | title = Film Festival Schedule - Drag Me to Hell (Work in Progress) | url = http://sxsw.com/film/screenings/schedule/?a=show&s=F16660# | work = SXSW | location = Austin, Texas | year = 2009 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090314041225/http://sxsw.com/film/screenings/schedule/?a=show&s=F16660 | archivedate = March 14, 2009 | accessdate = July 9, 2013}}</ref> The film debuted in its full form at the 2009 [[Cannes Film Festival]], where it was shown out of competition on May 20, 2009 as a midnight screening.<ref>{{cite web | title = Drag Me To Hell Premiere - 2009 Cannes Film Festival | url = http://www.zimbio.com/photos/Sam+Raimi/Drag+Hell+Premiere+2009+Cannes+Film+Festival/U5dIkLyJE3K | work = zimbio.com | date = May 20, 2009 | accessdate = 2018-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Recession-era movie Drag Me to Hell marks revenge of the repossessed | url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/may/21/sam-raimi-returns-to-horror | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = May 21, 2009 | accessdate = 2009-06-27 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Brown}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Out of Competition: "Drag Me to Hell" is a Midnight Screening | url = http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/theDailyArticle/56666.html | work = Cannes Film Festival Official Website | location = France | date = May 20, 2009 | accessdate = 2009-06-28}}</ref>
===Box office=== The film was released in American theaters on May 29, 2009.<ref name="metacritic" /> The film opened at #4 with $15,825,480 from 2,900 screens at 2,508 theaters, for an average of $6,310 per theater ($5,457 average per screen). In its second weekend, it dropped 56%, falling to #7, with $7,040,550 from 2,800 screens at 2,510 theaters, for an average of $2,805 per theater ($2,514 average per screen), and bringing the 10-day gross to $28,233,230.<ref name="the-numbers.com">{{cite web | url = http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2009/DRAGM.php | title = The Numbers - Box Office Data for Drag Me to Hell | accessdate = 2009-07-11 | publisher = [[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]}}</ref> ''Drag Me to Hell'' closed on August 6, 2009, with a final gross in the United States and Canada of $42,100,625, and an additional $48,742,021 internationally for a total of $90,842,646 worldwide.<ref name="boxofficemojo">{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=dragmetohell.htm | title = Drag Me to Hell (2009) | accessdate = November 23, 2010 | publisher = [[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref>
=== Critical response === ''Drag Me to Hell'' opened to critcal acclaim. On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film has an approval rating of 92% based on 262 reviews, and an [[Weighted arithmetic mean|average rating]] of 7.6/10. The site's critical consensus states, "Sam Raimi returns to top form with ''Drag Me to Hell'', a frightening, hilarious, delightfully campy thrill ride."<ref name="rottentomatoes">{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/drag_me_to_hell/|title=Drag Me to Hell|accessdate=December 2, 2018|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=IGN Entertainment, Inc}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]] the film has received an average score of 83 out of 100, based on 32 reviews, signifying "universal acclaim".<ref name="metacritic">{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/dragmetohell|title=Drag Me to Hell (2009): Reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=CNET Networks, Inc|accessdate=June 27, 2009}}</ref>
Positive critical reception of the film generally praised the film's scary but humorous and campy tone. Owen Gleiberman of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film an A rating, stating that "Raimi has made the most crazy, fun, and terrifying horror movie in years."<ref>{{cite web|last=Gleiberman|first=Owen|title=Drag Me to Hell > Movie Review > Entertainment Weekly|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20281263,00.html|date=May 27, 2009|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=June 28, 2009}}</ref> Betsy Sharkey of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' praised the film, stating that it "should not be dismissed as yet another horror flick just for teens. The filmmakers have given us a 10-story winding staircase of psychological tension that is making very small circles near the end."<ref>{{cite web|last=Sharkey|first=Betsy|title=Review: 'Drag Me to Hell'|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-drag29-2009may29,0,4792297.story|date=May 29, 2009|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=June 28, 2009}}</ref> [[Michael Phillips (critic)|Michael Phillips]] of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' described the film as a "hellaciously effective B-movie [that] comes with a handy moral tucked inside its scares, laughs and Raimi's specialty, the scare/laugh hybrid."<ref>{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Michael|title='Drag Me to Hell' stars Alison Lohman, Justin Long, David Paymer|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/lifestyle/chi-tc-mov-drag-me-to-hell-0527-may29,0,4474885.story|date=May 29, 2009|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=June 28, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611155449/http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/lifestyle/chi-tc-mov-drag-me-to-hell-0527-may29,0,4474885.story|archivedate=June 11, 2009}}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun Times]]'' gave the film 3 out of 4 stars, and stated that the film "is a sometimes funny and often startling horror movie. That is what it wants to be, and that is what it is."<ref>{{cite web | last = Ebert | first = Roger | title = 'Drag Me to Hell' Review | url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090603/REVIEWS/906079997/1001 | date = 2009-06-03 | work = [[Chicago Sun Times]] | accessdate = 2009-06-28}}</ref> In a positive review, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said of the film: "Scant and barren of subtext, the pic is single-mindedly devoted to pushing the audience's buttons... Still, there's no denying it delivers far more than competing PG-13 thrillers."<ref name="variety">{{cite web | last = Debruge | first = Peter | title = Drag Me to Hell Review | url = http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117940322.html?categoryid=31&cs=1 | date = 2009-05-20 | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | accessdate = 2009-06-28}}</ref>
[[Bloody Disgusting]] gave the film four and a half stars out of five, with the review calling it "quite simply the most PERFECT horror film I've seen in a long, long while... [It's] a blast and moved quickly from start to finish [and] is well on its way to becoming an immediate classic."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/film/1667/review|title=Drag Me to Hell|publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|accessdate=2010-01-03}}</ref> The film was then ranked thirteenth in Bloody Disgusting's list of the 'Top 20 Horror Films of the Decade'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18415|title=00's Retrospect: Bloody Disgusting's Top 20 Films of the Decade...Part 2|publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|accessdate=2010-01-03}}</ref>
[[Kyle Smith]] of the ''[[New York Post]]'' thought it was cheesy, with too many "gross-outs",<ref>{{cite web | last = Smith | first = Kyle |title=Fate Worse than Debt | url = http://www.nypost.com/seven/05292009/entertainment/movies/fate_worse_than_debt_171417.htm | date = 2009-05-29 | work = [[New York Post]] | accessdate = 2009-06-28}}</ref> [[Rex Reed]] of the ''[[New York Observer]]'' thought that the plot wasn't believable enough,<ref>{{cite web | last = Reed | first = Rex | title = What Has Happened to Sam Raimi? | url = http://www.observer.com/2009/movies/what-has-happened-sam-raimi | date = 2009-05-29 | work = [[New York Observer]] | accessdate = 2009-06-28}}</ref> and Peter Howell of ''[[The Toronto Star]]'' disliked Lohman's performance and thought it was "just not very funny".<ref>{{cite news | last = Howell | first = Peter | title = Drag Me to Hell: What a drag | url = https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/article/642230 | date = 2009-05-29 | work = [[The Toronto Star]] | accessdate = 2009-06-28}}</ref> The film was nominated for "Choice Movie: Horror/Thriller" at the 2009 [[Teen Choice Awards]], which the film lost to ''[[Friday the 13th (2009 film)|Friday the 13th]]'' (2009).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.ca/news/article.jhtml?id=19206|work=[[MTV]]|date=August 11, 2009|accessdate=2009-10-08|title=Teen Choice Awards Winners List|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217064459/http://www.mtv.ca/news/article.jhtml?id=19206|archivedate=February 17, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/awards/2009/06/teen-choice-awards-2009-nominees.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=June 15, 2009|accessdate=July 19, 2013|title=Teen Choice Awards 2009 nominees}}</ref> At the 2009 [[Scream Awards]] show, ''Drag Me to Hell'' won the awards for Best Horror Movie and Best [[Screenplay|Scream-play]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spike.com/event/scream2009/page/vote/category/33119|work=[[Spike (TV channel)|Spike]]|accessdate=July 9, 2013|title=Best Scream-Play: Scream 2009: Spike|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903020233/http://www.spike.com/event/scream2009/page/vote/category/33119|archivedate=September 3, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spike.com/event/scream2009/page/vote/category/33662|work=[[Spike (TV channel)|Spike]]|accessdate=July 9, 2013|title=Best Horror Movie: Scream 2009: Spike|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101209075932/http://www.spike.com/event/scream2009/page/vote/category/33662|archivedate=December 9, 2010}}</ref>
Reviews have also received the film as a [[comedy horror]] in a more classic [[Sam Raimi|Raimi]] vein. Vic Holtreman of Screenrant claims the film is a long-awaited movie that combines both genres as ''[[Army of Darkness]]'' had done.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://screenrant.com/drag-me-to-hell-reviews-vic-10582/ |title=Drag Me To Hell Review |publisher=Screen Rant |date=2009-05-28 |accessdate=2010-03-22}}</ref> A reviewer at [[UGO Networks]] says that the film is very much more a comedy than horror and that this is in keeping with [[Sam Raimi|Raimi]] not having produced a "true horror" film since he began directing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ugo.com/movies/drag-me-to-hell-review-should-have-just-been-evil-dead |title=Drag Me To Hell Review - Should Have Just Been Evil Dead |publisher=UGO.com |date=2009-05-21 |accessdate=2010-03-22}}</ref>
===Home media=== ''Drag Me to Hell'' was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc]] in the US on October 13, 2009. Both media include an Unrated Director's Cut as well as the Theatrical Version.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/drag-me-to-hell-v427518/releases|title=Drag Me to Hell (2009) - Releases|accessdate=July 9, 2013|work=[[Allmovie]]}}</ref> In its first two weeks the DVD sold 459,217 copies generating $7.98 million in sales.<ref name="test">{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2009/DRAGM-DVD.php |title=Drag Me To Hell - DVD Sales |publisher=The-numbers.com |date= |accessdate=July 9, 2013}}</ref> It since accumulated $13.9 million in DVD sales in the United States.
On February 13th, 2018, [[Scream Factory]] released a two-disc Collector's Edition of ''Drag Me to Hell'', which included both edits of the film remastered from the 2k digital intermediate, archival interviews and featurettes and all-new interviews with [[Alison Lohman]], [[Lorna Raver]] and [[Christopher Young]].
